prior_works.title: Doubly Robust Policy Evaluation and Learning
prior_works.authors: Miroslav Dudík, John Langford, Lihong Li
prior_works.role: Foundational doubly robust (DR) estimator for learning/evaluation under logged bandit feedback
prior_works.relationship_sentence: This paper’s new DR estimators for collaborative filtering build directly on the DR principle—unbiasedness if either the outcome (imputation) model or the propensity model is correct—originally formalized by Dudík et al.

prior_works.title: Counterfactual Risk Minimization: Learning from Logged Bandit Feedback
prior_works.role: Introduced IPS/SNIPS-based learning objectives and variance control for counterfactual learning
prior_works.relationship_sentence: The proposed propensity reconstruction and variance control mechanisms inherit the IPS/SNIPS counterfactual learning framework of Swaminathan and Joachims, while extending it with DR structure and adaptive weighting.

prior_works.title: Recommendations as Treatments: Debiasing Learning and Evaluation
prior_works.authors: Tobias Schnabel, Adith Swaminathan, Ashudeep Singh, Navin Chandak, Thorsten Joachims
prior_works.role: Brought propensity scoring and inverse propensity weighted matrix factorization to recommender systems
prior_works.relationship_sentence: By establishing IPS-based debiasing for recommendation, this work provides the recommender-specific foundation that the present paper generalizes with DR estimators robust to imperfect pseudo-label imputation.

prior_works.title: Unbiased Learning-to-Rank with Biased Feedback
prior_works.authors: Thorsten Joachims, Adith Swaminathan, Tobias Schnabel
prior_works.role: Demonstrated propensity estimation and IPW for debiasing biased implicit feedback in ranking
prior_works.relationship_sentence: The present paper extends the propensity-based debiasing paradigm exemplified here by introducing DR estimators that remain unbiased even when pseudo-labels exhibit structured user/item-specific biases.

prior_works.title: Modeling User Exposure in Recommendation
prior_works.authors: Dawen Liang, Laurent Charlin, James McInerney, David M. Blei
prior_works.role: Introduced explicit exposure modeling to address selection bias in implicit-feedback recommendation
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Because exposure models effectively impute missing labels, this work motivates the paper’s focus on relaxing the accurate-imputation assumption by designing DR estimators tolerant to systematic imputation bias.

prior_works.title: Collaborative Filtering and the Missing at Random Assumption
prior_works.authors: Benjamin M. Marlin, Richard S. Zemel
prior_works.role: Established that recommendation data are typically MNAR, causing biased learning without correction
prior_works.relationship_sentence: The paper’s debiasing objective and DR formulations directly respond to the MNAR problem identified by Marlin and Zemel by leveraging propensities and robust outcome models to achieve unbiasedness.

synthesis_narrative:
The paper’s core advance—doubly robust estimators for debiased collaborative filtering that remain unbiased even when pseudo-labels are imperfect with user- or item-specific inductive biases—sits at the intersection of counterfactual learning, propensity-based debiasing, and exposure/imputation modeling. Marlin and Zemel’s demonstration that recommender data are missing-not-at-random (MNAR) motivates the need for principled debiasing beyond standard CF. In response, Schnabel et al. ported inverse propensity scoring (IPS) to recommendation, and Joachims et al. operationalized propensity estimation for biased implicit feedback, establishing the counterfactual learning toolkit in this domain. However, IPS alone can suffer from high variance and relies critically on accurate propensity models. Dudík et al.’s doubly robust (DR) framework provides a remedy by guaranteeing unbiasedness if either the outcome model or the propensity model is correct, inspiring the present paper’s DR estimators tailored to collaborative filtering.

At the same time, exposure-based recommendation (Liang et al.) models unobserved exposures and effectively imputes labels, but its validity hinges on accurate imputation—precisely the assumption this paper relaxes. Building on Swaminathan and Joachims’ CRM/SNIPS perspective on variance control, the paper adds a propensity reconstruction learning mechanism with adaptive (attention-based) weighting to stabilize estimation while preserving DR guarantees. Collectively, these works enable the authors to (1) formalize DR estimators that tolerate structured imputation biases at the user or item level, and (2) couple them with practical propensity estimation and variance control, yielding a learning objective that is provably unbiased under realistic deviations from perfect pseudo-labeling.
